metadata.sermon_start_end: IF YOU look at your bulletin, on page 2 in the left-hand column, you will see the calendar of the week. Look at the events for Tuesday. These are the listings: staff meeting, organ recital, social hour, dinner, parish meeting, and “No New Life”! [...] In this sacrifice, toward which the church begins to move in Epiphany, there is a whole new world where everything is changed, where hope appears in the midst of hopelessness, where the promises of God break through to the exiles, where even the smallest acts of human charity signify the coming of the time when water will spring up in all our deserts, the dead will be raised, and all our sins and foolishness will be no more. AMEN.!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first thesis by treating a massive block (Isaiah 40-55) rather than a specific pericope. It functions as a thematic survey of 'newness' rather than an exposition of a single passage. It treats the Bible as a source of 'ideas' rather than a specific proclamatory word.
quotes: His work comes down to us in chapters 40–55 of the book of Isaiah.
No other part of the Bible puts forward the promise of the new as continually and as rapturously as Second Isaiah does.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific pericope (e.g., Isaiah 43:16-21) and find the unique point in that text that exists nowhere else, rather than summarizing 15 chapters.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates knowledge of the Babylonian Exile and the theological crisis of the 4th century B.C. However, the exegesis remains at the level of historical overview rather than deep linguistic or textual analysis.
quotes: It certainly must have assailed the people of Israel in Old Testament times, during the time of the Babylonian Exile in the fourth century B.C.
Yahweh, unlike other gods, was a jealous god. He would tolerate no rivals.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond general historical context to specific textual exegesis of the Hebrew nuances of 'new things' (hadashot) versus 'former things'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: Strong and concrete. The use of the Port Authority Bus Terminal and the specific grief of a parishioner avoids the 'general truths' Dekker forbids. It connects the 'zeitgeist' of New York to the 'zeitgeist' of Babylon.
quotes: The story in yesterday’s New York Times of the homeless young people who panhandle by day and live in the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
I didn’t want a New Year that didn’t have my mother in it!
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows strictly from the text's unique point rather than using the text as a hook for social commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat 'blocky' structure: contemporary anecdote, then historical context, then scripture quotes, then contemporary stories. It lacks the seamless 'mixing' Dekker requires where the hearer is 'expounded' by the text.
quotes: In just this situation, the second prophet Isaiah carried out his ministry.
Here is a story of two parishioners, just this past week.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'sandwich' method (anecdote-text-anecdote). Try to let the contemporary reality be interpreted by the biblical vocabulary throughout the sermon.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly addresses 'misery' (exile, addiction, grief) and 'redemption' (pardon, new life). 'Gratitude' is less prominent but implied in the 'new song'. It correctly identifies misery as being 'before God'.
quotes: They had forsaken him; therefore, it seemed, he had forsaken them.
God’s power to call a new creation into being is dependent not upon our merits but upon his own nature.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Make the 'gratitude' (the third part) more explicit as a response of the Spirit-led life, rather than just a future hope.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon leans heavily toward universal comfort. While it mentions the 'detestable' nature of idols, the 'two ways' (the possibility of being lost) is softened by the emphasis on 'unconditional' gift-giving. The seriousness of the 'narrow way' is missing.
quotes: He does not ask us what we are doing to make ourselves better; he just gives the gift.
He does not ask if we are working to turn ourselves around... he puts redemption into our blanket.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the responsibility of the hearer. If 'human choices matter' (Thesis 6), the sermon must articulate the consequence of remaining in idolatry.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is explicitly Christocentric, identifying Christ as the 'telos'. It correctly employs the doctrine of the two natures (God become man) and views the OT through the lens of the Cross.
quotes: God has become man... come down in the person of his Son to be dunked in the muddy waters.
The ultimate glory of God is to be brought about by the ultimate sacrifice.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the transition from Isaiah to Christ is exegetically grounded in the 'Servant' passages rather than just a liturgical leap.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 21 minutes, the sermon meets Dekker's minimum requirement for 'breadth'. It allows for psychological and social depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Maintain this length but increase the density of specific textual exposition.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails Dekker's primary formal requirement by not focusing on a specific Bible passage, instead surveying fifteen chapters. It also lacks the 'two ways' tension, leaning toward a one-sided grace that risks making human choice irrelevant. However, it excels in concrete application and maintains a strong Christological focus.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of the Port Authority and specific parishioner grief avoids generalities.
Christocentricity: Christ is clearly the telos and the source of salvation outside the self.
Psychological depth: It addresses the 'misery' of the human condition (addiction, grief) with sobriety.
weaknesses: Lack of textual specificity: Treating Isaiah 40-55 as a whole prevents the 'specific word' from emerging.
Absence of the 'Two Ways': The sermon lacks the urgency of human responsibility and the danger of being lost.
Structural separation: Exposition and application are often placed in separate blocks.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong 'speech about the Gospel' but, according to Dekker's strict definition (Thesis 1.3), it is not yet a 'sermon' because it lacks a specific pericope as its foundation. It is too thematic and lacks the 'narrow way' of human responsibility.
